By late 2019, it should dim to 34 mag. }} '''ʻOumuamua''' ({{IPAc-en|audio=Haw-oumuamua.oga|ʔ|oʊ|ˌ|m|uː|ə|ˈ|m|uː|ə}}) is the first [[interstellar object]] detected passing through the [[Solar System]]. [[Naming of comets#Current system|Formally designated]] '''1I/2017 U1''', it was discovered by [[Robert Weryk]] using the [[Pan-STARRS]] telescope at [[Haleakala Observatory]], Hawaii, on 19 October 2017, 40 days after it passed its closest point to the Sun. When first seen, it was about {{cvt|{{#expr: 85*384400 round -6}}|km|mi AU|lk=on}} from Earth (about 85 times as far away as the Moon), and already heading away from the Sun. ʻOumuamua is a small object, estimated to be about {{convert|100|-|1000|x|35|-|167|x|35|-|167|m|ft|abbr=on}} in size. It has a dark red color, similar to objects in the [[outer Solar System]]. ʻOumuamua showed no signs of a [[comet tail]] despite its close approach to the Sun, but has since undergone non-gravitational acceleration, potentially consistent with a push from solar radiation pressure. It has significant elongation and rotation rate, so it is thought to be metal-rich with a relatively high density. ʻOumuamua is [[tumbling (rigid body)|tumbling]], rather than smoothly rotating, and is moving so fast relative to the Sun that there is no chance it originated in the Solar System. It also means that ʻOumuamua cannot be captured into a solar orbit, so it will eventually leave the Solar System and resume traveling through [[interstellar space]]. ʻOumuamua's [[Planetary system|system of origin]] and the amount of time it has spent traveling amongst the stars are unknown. == Nomenclature == [[File:Oumuamua orbit at perihelion.png|thumb|left|[[Hyperbolic trajectory]] of ʻOumuamua through the [[inner Solar System]] with the Sun at the [[focus (geometry)|focus]] ([https://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/archive/PIA22357_JPL-20180620-ASTRDSf-0007-Interstellar%20Asteroid%20animation-720p.mp4 animation])]] As the first known object of its type, ʻOumuamua presented a unique case for the [[International Astronomical Union]], which assigns designations for astronomical objects. Originally classified as comet '''C/2017 U1''', it was later reclassified as asteroid '''A/2017 U1''', due to the absence of a [[Coma (cometary)|coma]]. Once it was unambiguously identified as coming from outside the Solar System, a [[Naming of comets#Current system|new designation]] was created: '''I''', for Interstellar object. ʻOumuamua, as the first object so identified, was designated 1I, with rules on the eligibility of objects for I-numbers, and the names to be assigned to these interstellar objects, yet to be codified. The object may be referred to as 1I; 1I/2017 U1; 1I/ʻOumuamua; or 1I/2017 U1 (ʻOumuamua). The name comes {{ety|haw|[[wikt:ʻoumuamua#Hawaiian|ʻoumuamua]]|scout}} ({{ety||[[wikt:ʻou#Hawaiian|ʻou]]|reach out for||[[wikt:mua#Hawaiian|mua]]{{noitalic|, [[reduplication|reduplicated]] for emphasis}}|first, in advance of}}), and reflects the way this object is like a scout or messenger sent from the distant past to reach out to humanity. It roughly translates to "first distant messenger".{{cite web |url=https://www.outerplaces.com/science/item/17035-interstellar-object-asteroid-oumuamua |title=Our Solar System's First Interstellar Asteroid is Named ʻOumuamua' |last=Kesh |first=Johnathan |date=8 November 2017 |website=Outer Places |access-date=23 November 2017 |df=dmy-all}} The first character is a Hawaiian [[ʻOkina|ʻokina]], not an [[apostrophe]], and is represented by a [[single quotation mark]] and pronounced as a [[glottal stop]]; the name was chosen by the Pan-STARRS team{{Cite magazine |last=Wall |first=Mike |date=16 November 2017 |title=Meet ʻOumuamua, the First-Ever Asteroid from Another Star |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/meet-oumuamua-the-first-ever-asteroid-from-another-star |magazine=Scientific American |language=en |via=Space.com}} in consultation with Kaʻiu Kimura and [[Larry Kimura]] of the [[University of Hawaii at Hilo]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.hawaii.edu/news/2017/11/20/an-interstellar-visitor-unmasked |title=An interstellar visitor unmasked |last=Gal |first=Roy |date=20 November 2017 |work=University of Hawaiʻi System News |access-date=22 November 2017 |language=en-US |df=dmy-all}} Before the official name was decided upon, the name ''Rama'' was suggested, the name given to an alien spacecraft discovered under similar circumstances in the 1973 science fiction novel ''[[Rendezvous with Rama]]'' by [[Arthur C. Clarke]].{{cite magazine |title=The first visitor from another solar system has just been spotted: Rendezvous with Rama? |magazine=The Economist |date=2 November 2017 |url=https://www.economist.com/news/science-and-technology/21730863-rendezvous-rama-first-visitor-another-solar-system-has-just-been}} == Observations == [[File:A2017U1 5gsmoothWHT enhanced.jpg|thumb|left|ʻOumuamua, imaged here with the William Herschel Telescope on 28 October, is seen as a stationary light source in the center of the image. Background stars appear streaked because the telescope is tracking the rapidly moving object.]] Observations and conclusions concerning the trajectory of ʻOumuamua were primarily obtained with data from the [[Pan-STARRS#Instruments|Pan-STARRS1 Telescope]], part of the [[Spaceguard|Spaceguard Survey]],{{cite journal |last1=Morrison |first1=David |authorlink=David Morrison (astrophysicist) |title=Interstellar Visitor: The Strange Asteroid from a Faraway System |journal=Skeptical Inquirer |date=March–April 2018 |volume=42 |issue=2 |pages=5–6}} and the [[Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope]] (CFHT), and its composition and shape from the [[Very Large Telescope]] and the [[Gemini South]] telescope in Chile,{{cite press release |website=Gemini Observatory |url=http://www.gemini.edu/node/12729 |title=First Known Interstellar Visitor is an 'Oddball' |date=20 November 2017 |access-date=28 November 2017}} as well as the [[W. M. Keck Observatory|Keck II]] telescope in Hawaii. These were collected by [[Karen J. Meech]], Robert Weryk and their colleagues and published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' on 20 November, 2017.{{Cite newspaper |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-42053634 |title=Bizarre shape of interstellar asteroid |journal=BBC News |first=Paul |last=Rincon |date=20 November 2017 |access-date=20 November 2017 }} Post announcement, the space-based telescopes [[Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble]] and [[Spitzer Space Telescope|Spitzer]] joined in the observations. [[File:Oumuamua magnitude 2015-2019.png|thumb|left|ʻOumuamua will fade to 34th apparent magnitude by 2020]] ʻOumuamua is small and dark. It was not seen in [[STEREO|STEREO HI-1A]] observations near its perihelion on 9 September 2017, limiting its brightness to ~13.5 mag. By the end of October, ʻOumuamua had already faded to [[apparent magnitude]] ~23, and by mid-December 2017, it was expected to be too faint and fast moving to be studied by even the largest ground-based telescopes. ʻOumuamua was compared to the fictional alien spacecraft ''Rama'' because of its interstellar origin. Adding to the coincidence, both the real and the fictional objects are unusually elongated and limited in size. However, ʻOumuamua has a reddish hue and unsteady brightness, which are typical of asteroids.{{cite magazine |first=John |last=Wenz |magazine=Astronomy |url=http://www.astronomy.com/news/2017/11/interstellar-asteroid-is-a-quarter-mile-long-red-beast |title=The first discovered interstellar asteroid is a quarter-mile long red beast |date=22 November 2017}}{{cite news |last=Overbye |first=Dennis |authorlink=Dennis Overbye |title=An Interstellar Visitor Both Familiar and Alien |date=22 November 2017 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/22/science/oumuamua-space-asteroid.html |accessdate=23 November 2017}}{{cite news |first=Seth |last=Shostak |title=Is this mysterious space rock actually an alien spaceship? |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/mach/science/mysterious-space-rock-actually-alien-spaceship-ncna829501 |work=[[NBC News]] |date=14 December 2017 |accessdate=20 December 2017}} The [[SETI Institute]]'s [[radio telescope]], the [[Allen Telescope Array]], examined ʻOumuamua, but detected no unusual [[radio emission]]s. More detailed observations, using the [[Breakthrough Listen]] hardware and the [[Green Bank Telescope]], were performed;{{Cite journal |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/oumuamua-is-not-an-interstellar-spacecraft |title=It isn't an alien spacecraft, but we should still study ʻOumuamua |last=Beall |first=Abigail |date=12 December 2017 |journal=Wired UK |access-date=12 December 2017}} the data were searched for narrowband signals and none were found. Given the close proximity to this interstellar object, limits were placed to putative transmitters with the extremely low power of 0.08 watts.{{Cite arxiv |eprint=1801.02814 |title=Breakthrough Listen Observations of 1I/ʻOumuamua with the GBT |last=Enriquez |first=J. E. |date=9 January 2018 |class=astro-ph.EP}} === Trajectory === [[File:Oumuamua-skypath.png|thumb|left|Seen from Earth, the [[Apparent place|apparent trajectory]] makes annual retrograde loops in the sky, with its origin in [[Lyra (constellation)|Lyra]], temporarily moving south of the ecliptic between 6 September and 16 October 2017, and moving northward again towards its destination in [[Pegasus (constellation)|Pegasus]].]] [[File:Oumuamua-solar system-ecliptic-normals.png|thumb|ʻOumuamua's hyperbolic trajectory over the Solar System]] ʻOumuamua appears to have come from roughly the direction of [[Vega]] in the constellation [[Lyra (constellation)|Lyra]].{{cite news |first=Jamie |last=Seidel |title='Alien' object excites astronomers. Is it a 'visitor' from nearby star? |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/technology/news/article.cfm?c_id=5&objectid=11937034 |publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |date=26 October 2017}} The incoming direction of motion of ʻOumuamua is 6° from the [[solar apex]] (the direction of the Sun's movement relative to local stars), which is the most likely direction for approaches from objects outside the Solar System. On 26 October, two [[precovery]] observations from the [[Catalina Sky Survey]] were found dated 14 and 17 October. A two-week [[observation arc]] had verified a strongly [[hyperbolic trajectory]]. It has a [[hyperbolic excess velocity]] (velocity at infinity, v_{\infty}\!) of {{cvt|26.33|km/s|kph}}, its speed relative to the Sun when in interstellar space.For comparison, comet C/1980 E1 will only be moving 4.2 km/s when it is 500 AU from the Sun. {| class="wikitable floatright" style="text-align:center; font-size:0.9em;" |+ ʻOumuamua speed relative to the Sun{{cite web |url=https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=2017U1 |title=Horizons Web-Interface |website=Solar System Dynamics Group |publisher=[[JPL]]}} Results produced with [[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System]] using Soln.date: 2017-Nov-21. They have named it 1I/2017 U1 (ʻOumuamua) and estimate it could be one of 10,000 others lurking undetected in our cosmic neighbourhood. |language=en-GB}} Based on observations spanning 34 days, ʻOumuamua's [[orbital eccentricity]] is 1.20, the highest ever observed. An [[hyperbola|eccentricity exceeding 1.0]] means an object exceeds the Sun's [[escape velocity]], is not bound to the Solar System and may escape to interstellar space. While an eccentricity slightly above 1.0 can be obtained by encounters with planets, as happened with the previous record holder, [[C/1980 E1 (Bowell)|C/1980 E1]],{{refn |group="Note" |Unlike ʻOumuamua, C/1980 E1's orbit got its high eccentricity of 1.057 due to a close encounter with [[Jupiter]]. Its inbound-orbit eccentricity was less than 1.}} ʻOumuamua's eccentricity is so high that it could not have been obtained through an encounter with any of the planets in the Solar System. Even undiscovered planets in the Solar System, if any should exist, could not account for ʻOumuamua's trajectory nor boost its speed to the observed value. For these reasons, ʻOumuamua can only be of interstellar origin.{{cite journal |title=On Distinguishing Interstellar Objects Like ʻOumuamua From Products of Solar System Scattering |year=2018 |journal=Research Notes of the AAS |volume=1 |issue=1 |page=38 |doi=10.3847/2515-5172/aa9f23 |bibcode=2017RNAAS...1a..38W |arxiv=1712.06044|last1=Wright |first1=Jason T. |last2=Jones |first2=Hugh R.A. }}{{cite journal |last1=de la Fuente Marcos |first1=Carlos |last2=de la Fuente Marcos |first2=Raúl |last3=Aarseth |first3=Sverre J. |year=2018 |title=Where the Solar system meets the solar neighbourhood: patterns in the distribution of radiants of observed hyperbolic minor bodies |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society Letters |volume=476 |issue=1 |pages=L1–L5 |arxiv=1802.00778 |bibcode=2018MNRAS.476L...1D |doi=10.1093/mnrasl/sly019 |url=https://academic.oup.com/mnrasl/article-abstract/476/1/L1/4840245}} [[File:Comet 20171025-16 gif.gif|left|thumb|Animation of ʻOumuamua passing through the Solar System]] {| class="wikitable floatright" style="text-align:center; font-size:0.9em;" |+ Inbound velocity at 200 AU from the Sun

Short arcs can result in computer generated orbits rejecting some data unnecessarily. |- | [[90377 Sedna]] || 1.99 || 196 in 9240 days |- | [[C/1980 E1 (Bowell)]] || 2.96 || 179 in 2514 days |- | C/1997 P2 (Spacewatch) || 2.96 || 94 in 49 days |- | [[C/2010 X1 (Elenin)]] || 2.96 || 2222 in 235 days |- | [[C/2012 S1 (ISON)]] || 2.99 || 6514 in 784 days |- | C/2008 J4 (McNaught) || 4.88 || 22 in 15 daysOther orbital solutions show [https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/mpml/conversations/messages/33402 C/2008 J4 entering the Solar System @ 3.5 ± 1.3 km/s.] JPL #10 shows that on 1855-Mar-24 C/2008 J4 was moving 4.88 ± 1.8 km/s. |- | '''1I/2017 U1 (ʻOumuamua)''' || 26.5 || 121 in 34 days |} ʻOumuamua entered the Solar System from north of the plane of the [[ecliptic]]. The pull of the Sun's gravity caused it to speed up until it reached its maximum speed of {{cvt|87.71|km/s|kph}} as it passed south of the ecliptic on 6 September and made a sharp turn upward at its closest approach to the Sun (perihelion) on 9 September at a distance of {{cvt|0.255|AU|km mi|lk=on}} from the Sun, i.e., about 17% closer than [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]'s closest approach to the Sun.{{refn |group="Note" |Comet [[C/2012 S1 (ISON)]] peaked at {{cvt|377|km/s|kph}} at perihelion{{cite web |url=http://www.isoncampaign.org/karl/ison-is-just-fine |first=Karl |last=Battams |website=NASA Comet ISON Observing Campaign |title=Comet ISON is doing just fine! |date=9 October 2013 |access-date=12 December 2017}} because it passed 0.0124 AU from the Sun (20 times closer than ʻOumuamua).}} The object is now heading away from the Sun towards [[Pegasus (constellation)|Pegasus]] at an angle of 66° from the direction of its approach.According to the formula: [[Hyperbolic trajectory#Eccentricity and angle between approach and departure|{{big|1=2\,\theta{_\infty}=2\cos^{-1}(-1/e)}}]] On the outward leg of its journey through the Solar System, ʻOumuamua passed within the orbit of Earth on 14 October at a distance of approximately {{cvt|0.1616|AU|km mi|lk=on}} from Earth, and went back north of the ecliptic on 16 October and passed beyond the orbit of Mars on 1 November. It passed beyond Jupiter's orbit in May 2018, and will pass beyond Saturn's orbit in January 2019 and Neptune's orbit in 2022. As it leaves the Solar System it will be approximately [[right ascension]] 23h51m and [[declination]] +24°45', in [[Pegasus (constellation)|Pegasus]]. It will continue to slow down until it reaches a speed of 26.33 km/s relative to the Sun, the same speed it had before its approach to the Solar System. It will take the object roughly 20,000 years to leave the Solar System completely.Given that the [[Oort cloud]] is the furthest reaches of the Solar System, define the [[Solar system#Boundaries|edge of the Solar System]] at {{convert|2|ly|AU e12km |abbr=off|lk=on|sigfig=2|sp=us}} and assume an average velocity of 26.3 km/s. It will take the object 23,000 years to reach 2 light–years ({{convert|2|ly|km |sigfig=2|disp=out}} / 26.3 km-per-sec / 60 seconds-per-min / 60 minutes-per-hour / 24 hours-per-day / 365.25 days-per-year = 23,000 years) On 27 June 2018, astronomers reported a non-gravitational acceleration to ʻOumuamua's trajectory, potentially consistent with a push from solar radiation pressure. Initial speculation as to the cause of this acceleration pointed to comet off-gassing, whereby portions of the object are ejected as the sun heats the surface. However, multiple objections have been raised to this possibility. Researchers point out that no such tail of gasses was ever observed following the object. Additionally, the anomalous acceleration was not observed when ʻOumuamua was passing at its closest to the sun as would be expected. A follow up analysis of these claims identifies that, were ʻOumuamua a comet, the off-gassing should have caused such an increase in rotational torque as to tear the object apart. ==== Indications of origin ==== Accounting for Vega's [[proper motion]], it would have taken ʻOumuamua 600,000 years to reach the Solar System from Vega. But as a nearby star, Vega was not in the same part of the sky at that time. Astronomers calculate that one hundred years ago the asteroid was {{convert|561|±|0.6|AU|e9km e9mi |round=each |abbr=unit}} from the Sun and traveling at 26.33 km/s with respect to the Sun. This interstellar speed is very close to the mean motion of material in the Milky Way in the neighborhood of the Sun, also known as the [[local standard of rest]] (LSR), and especially close to the mean motion of a relatively close group of [[red dwarf]] stars. This velocity profile also indicates an [[extrasolar]] origin, but appears to rule out the [[List of nearest stars and brown dwarfs|closest dozen stars]]. In fact, the strong correlation between ʻOumuamua's velocity and the local standard of rest might mean that it has circulated the Milky Way several times and thus may have originated from an entirely different part of the galaxy. It is unknown how long the object has been traveling among the stars. The Solar System is likely the first star system that ʻOumuamua has closely encountered since being ejected from its birth star system, potentially several billion years ago. It has been speculated that the object may have been ejected from a stellar system in one of the local [[Stellar kinematic group|kinematic associations]] of [[young star]]s (specifically, [[Carina OB1|Carina]] or Columba) within a range of about 100 parsecs,{{cite journal |year=2013 |title=Unveiling new members in ﬁve nearby young moving groups |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society |volume=435 |issue=2 |pages=1376–1388 |doi=10.1093/mnras/stt1381 |arxiv=1309.1669 |last1=Moór |first1=A. |last2=Szabó |first2=Gy. M. |last3=Kiss |first3=L.L. |last4=Kiss |first4=Cs. |last5=Ábrahám |first5=P. |last6=Szulágyi |first6=J. |last7=Kóspál |first7=Á. |last8=Szalai |first8=T. |bibcode=2013MNRAS.435.1376M}} some 45 million years ago. The Carina and Columba associations are now very far in the sky from the [[Lyra]] constellation, the direction from which ʻOumuamua came when it entered the Solar System. Others have speculated that it was ejected from a white dwarf system and that its volatiles were lost when its parent star became a red giant.{{cite arXiv |last1=Hansen |first1=B. |last2=Zuckerman |first2=B. |title=Ejection of material – "Jurads" – from post main sequence planetary systems |eprint=1712.07247 |class= astro-ph.EP |date=19 December 2017}} About 1.3 million years ago the object may have passed within a distance of {{convert|0.16|pc|abbr=off|lk=on}} to the nearby star TYC 4742-1027-1, but its velocity is too high to have originated from that star system, and it probably just passed through the system's [[Oort cloud]] at a speed of {{cvt|103|km/s|kph}}.This is true for the nominal position of the star. However, its actual distance is not known precisely: According to [[Gaia Data Release 1]], the distance to TYC4742-1027-1 is {{convert|137|±|13|pc|abbr=off|lk=on}}. It is not known if an encounter actually occurred. Update: This star has new measurements in [[Gaia Data Release 2]], and an origins study based on this by Bailer-Jones et al. (2018) shows that TYC4742-1027-1 did not come within 2pc of ʻOumuamua. A more recent study (August 2018) using [[Gaia Data Release 2]] has updated the possible past close encounters and has identified four stars that ʻOumuamua passed relatively close to and at moderately low velocities in the past few million years. {{cite journal |last1=Bailer-Jones |first=Coryn A.L. |display-authors=etal |title=Plausible home stars of the interstellar object ʻOumuamua found in Gaia DR2 |journal=Astronomical Journal |date=2018-10-18 |volume=156 |issue=5 |page=205 |ref=Bailer-Jones2018|doi=10.3847/1538-3881/aae3eb |arxiv=1809.09009 }} This study also identifies future close encounters of ʻOumuamua on its outgoing trajectory from the Sun.{{cite journal |last1=Bailer-Jones |first=Coryn A.L. |display-authors=etal |title=Plausible home stars of the interstellar object ʻOumuamua found in Gaia DR2 |url=http://www.mpia.de/homes/calj/gdr2_oumuamua.html}} According to one hypothesis, ʻOumuamua could be a fragment from a [[Disrupted planet|tidally disrupted planet]].{{Cite journal |last=Ćuk |first=Matija |arxiv=1712.01823 |title=1I/ʻOumuamua as a Tidal Disruption Fragment From a Binary Star System |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=852 |issue=1 |pages=L15 |date=19 December 2017 |doi=10.3847/2041-8213/aaa3db |bibcode=2018ApJ...852L..15C}}See also {{cite arxiv |eprint=1801.02658v2|last1=Ravikov|first1=Roman R. |title=1I/2017 ʻOumuamua-like Interstellar Asteroids as Possible Messengers from the Dead Stars |class=astro-ph.EP |year=2018}}, ʻOumuamua is a fragment of a white-dwarf-star tidal-disruption-event. This easily explains its 6:1 or 10:1 elongation and its "refractory" composition; containing probably nickel-iron, possibly other metals, too. If true, this would make ʻOumuamua a rare object, of a type much less abundant than most extrasolar "dusty-snowball" comets or asteroids. === Classification === Initially, ʻOumuamua was announced as comet C/2017 U1 (PANSTARRS) based on a strongly hyperbolic trajectory. In an attempt to confirm any cometary activity, very deep [[Shift-and-add|stacked images]] were taken at the [[Very Large Telescope]] later the same day, but the object showed no presence of a [[Coma (cometary)|coma]].According to [[Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams]]'s CBET 4450, none of the observers had detected any sign of cometary activity. The initial classification as a comet was based on the object's orbit. Accordingly, the object was renamed A/2017 U1, becoming the first comet ever to be [[Naming of comets#Current system|re-designated as an asteroid]]. Once it was identified as an interstellar object, it was designated 1I/2017 U1, the first member of a new class of objects. The lack of a coma limits the amount of surface ice to a few square meters, and any [[volatiles]] (if they exist) must lie below a crust at least {{cvt|0.5|m|ft}} thick. It also indicates that the object must have formed within the [[Frost line (astrophysics)|frost line]] of its parent stellar system or have been in the inner region of that stellar system long enough for all near-surface ice to [[Sublimation (phase transition)|sublimate]], as may be the case with [[damocloid]]s.{{Citation needed|reason=Not mentioned in previous cited source|date=January 2018}} It is difficult to say which scenario is more likely due to the chaotic nature of small body dynamics,{{Citation needed|reason=Not mentioned in previous cited source|date=January 2018}} although if it formed in a similar manner to Solar System objects, its spectrum indicates that the latter scenario is true. Any [[meteor|meteoric activity]] from ʻOumuamua would have been expected to occur on 18 October 2017 coming from the constellation [[Sextans]], but no activity was detected by the Canadian Meteor Orbit Radar. On 27 June 2018, astronomers reported that ʻOumuamua was thought to be a mildly active [[comet]], and not an [[asteroid]], as previously thought. This was determined by measuring a non-gravitational boost to ʻOumuamua's acceleration, consistent with comet outgassing. However, studies submitted in October 2018 suggest that the object is neither an asteroid nor a comet.{{cite arxiv |last=Rafikov |first=Roman R. |title=Spin Evolution and Cometary Interpretation of the Interstellar Minor Object 1I/2017 ʻOumuamua |date=20 September 2018 |eprint=1809.06389v2 |class=astro-ph.EP}}{{cite web |last=Skibba |first=Ramin |title=Interstellar Visitor Found to Be Unlike a Comet or an Asteroid |url=https://www.quantamagazine.org/interstellar-comet-oumuamua-might-not-actually-be-a-comet-20181010/ |date=10 October 2018 |work=[[Quanta Magazine]] |accessdate=10 October 2018 }} === Appearance, shape, and composition === Spectra recorded by the {{cvt|4.2|m}} [[William Herschel Telescope]] on 25 October showed that the object was featureless, and [[Trans-Neptunian object#Colors|colored red]] like [[Kuiper belt]] objects. Spectra from the Hale Telescope showed a less-red color resembling comet nuclei or [[Trojan (astronomy)|Trojans]]. Its spectrum is similar to that of [[D-type asteroid]]s. [[File:Eso1737f.jpg|thumb|upright=2.3|[[Light curve]] from 25–27 October 2017 with dotted line from a model with 10:1 elongation]] ʻOumuamua is rotating around a non-principal axis, a type of movement known as [[tumbling (rigid body)|tumbling]].{{cite journal |last1=Fraser |first1=W.C. |last2=Pravec |first2=P. |last3=Fitzsimmons |first3=A. |last4=Lacerda |first4=P. |last5=Bannister |first5=M.T. |last6=Snodgrass |first6=C. |last7=Smolić |first7=I. |title=The tumbling rotational state of 1I/‘Oumuamua |journal=Nature Astronomy |volume=2 |issue=5 |pages=383–386 |date=9 February 2018 |doi=10.1038/s41550-018-0398-z |arxiv=1711.11530 |bibcode=2018NatAs...2..383F |url=https://pure.qub.ac.uk/portal/en/publications/the-tumbling-rotational-state-of-1ioumuamua(cbcc0793-72c1-4f42-b78a-5bcdeff6274c).html }}{{cite arxiv |eprint=1712.00437 |title=Tumbling motion of 1I/ʻOumuamua reveals body's violent past |last1=Drahus |first1=M. |last2=Guzik |first2=P. |last3=Waniak |first3=W. |last4=Handzlik |first4=B. |last5=Kurowski |first5=S. |last6=Xu |first6=S. |class=astro-ph.EP |date=1 December 2017}} This accounts for the various rotation periods reported, such as 8.10 hours, (±0.42 hours) (±0.02 hours) with a lightcurve amplitude of {{nowrap|1.5–2.1 magnitudes}}, whereas Meech et al. reported a rotation period of 7.3 hours and a lightcurve amplitude of 2.5 magnitudes.[[1865 Cerberus]] has a lightcurve amplitude of 2.3 magnitudes. Most likely, ʻOumuamua was set tumbling by a collision in its system of origin, and remains tumbling since the time scale for dissipation of this motion is very long, at least a billion years.[https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-43018706 ʻOumuamua: 'space cigar's' tumble hints at violent past]. Jonathan Amos, ''BBC News'', 11 February 2018. [[File:Artist's impression of ʻOumuamua.jpg|thumb|left|Artist's impression of ʻOumuamua]] [[File:ʻOumuamua light curve simulation.gif|thumb|upright=1.5|Simulation of ʻOumuamua spinning and tumbling through space, and the resultant light curve. In reality, in all observations of ʻOumuamua the asteroid only constituted a single pixel and its shape was inferred from the light curve.]] The large variations on the light curves indicate that ʻOumuamua may be either a highly elongated object, comparable to or greater than the most elongated Solar System objects, or an extremely flat object, a pancake or oblate [[sphereoid]].{{cite arxiv |eprint=1804.03471 |title=The Excited Spin State of 1I/2017 U1 ‘Oumuamua |last1=Belton |first1=M.J.S. |display-authors=etal |class=astro-ph.EP |date=10 April 2018 |quote=We find that ‘Oumuamua is "cigar-shaped"', if close to its lowest rotational energy, and an extremely oblate spheroid if close to its highest energy state for its total angular momentum.}} However, the size and shape have not been directly observed as ʻOumuamua appears as nothing more than a point source of light even in the most powerful telescopes. Neither the [[Geometric albedo|albedo]] or triaxial ellipsoid shape are precisely known. If cigar-shaped, the longest-to-shortest axis ratio could be 5:1 or greater. Assuming an albedo of 10% (typical for D-type asteroids) and a 6:1 ratio, ʻOumuamua has dimensions of approximately {{convert|100|-|1000|x|35|-|167|x|35|-|167|m|ft|abbr=on}} with an average diameter of about {{cvt|110|m|ft}}. According to astronomer [[David Jewitt]], the object is physically unremarkable except for its highly elongated shape. Bannister et al. have suggested that it could also be a [[Contact binary (small Solar System body)|contact binary]], although this may not be compatible with its rapid rotation. One speculation regarding its shape is that it is a result of a violent event (such as a collision or stellar explosion) that caused its ejection from its system of origin. JPL News reported that ʻOumuamua "is up to one-quarter mile, {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=on}}, long and highly-elongated-perhaps 10 times as long as it is wide".{{cite web |title=Solar System's First |last5=Hyland |first6=T. |last6=Seccull |first7=M.T. |last7=Bannister |first8=W.C. |last8=Fraser |first9=R. |last9=Jedicke |first10=P. |last10=Lacerda |display-authors=1 |title=Spectroscopy and Despite the lack of any [[Coma (comet)|cometary coma]] when it approached the Sun, it may still contain internal ice, hidden by "an insulating mantle produced by long-term [[cosmic ray]] exposure". === Additional measurements === In December 2017, astronomer [[Avi Loeb]] of [[Harvard University]], an adviser to the [[Breakthrough Listen]] Project, cited ʻOumuamua's unusually elongated shape as one of the reasons why the [[Green Bank Telescope]] in [[West Virginia]] would listen for [[radio emission]]s from it to see if there were any unexpected signs that it might be of [[Extraterrestrial intelligence|artificial origin]], although earlier limited observations by other radio telescopes such as the [[SETI Institute]]'s [[Allen Telescope Array]] had produced no such results. On 13 December 2017, the Green Bank Telescope observed the asteroid for six hours across four bands of radio frequency. No radio signals from ʻOumuamua were detected in this very limited scanning range, but observations are ongoing.{{cite web |title=Breakthrough Listen Releases Initial Results and Data from Observations of ‘Oumuamua |url=http://breakthroughinitiatives.org/news/15 |publisher=Breakthrough Listen |date=13 December 2017 |accessdate=15 December 2017 |quote=No evidence of artificial signals emanating from the object so far detected by the Green Bank Telescope, but monitoring and analysis continue. Initial data are available for public inspection in the Breakthrough Listen archive}}{{Cite newspaper |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/dec/14/is-oumuamua-an-alien-spacecraft-first-scans-show-no-signs-of-technology |title=Is ‘Oumuamua an alien spacecraft? Initial scans show no signs of technology |journal=The Guardian |author=Ian Sample |date=15 December 2017 |accessdate=15 December 2017}} In September 2018, astronomers described several possible home [[star system]]s from which ʻOumuamua may have originated.{{Cite arxiv |eprint = 1809.09009|last1 = Feng|first1 = Fabo|title = Plausible home stars of the interstellar object ʻOumuamua found in Gaia DR2|last2 = Jones|first2 = Hugh R.A.|class = astro-ph.EP|year = 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.space.com/41928-where-did-oumuamua-come-from.html |title=ʻOumuamua Isn't from Our Solar System. Now We May Know Which Star It Came From |first=Meghan |last=Bartels |website=Space.com |date=25 September 2018}} On October 26, 2018, [[Avi Loeb]] and his postdoc Shmuel Bialy submitted a paper exploring the possibility of ʻOumuamua being an artificial thin [[solar sail]] accelerated by solar radiation pressure in an effort to help explain the object's non-gravitational acceleration.{{cite web |last=Williams |first=Matt |title=Could Oumuamua Be an Extra-Terrestrial Solar Sail? |url=https://www.universetoday.com/140391/could-oumuamua-be-an-extra-terrestrial-solar-sail/ |date=2 November 2018 |work=[[Universe Today]] |accessdate=2 November 2018 }}{{cite arxiv |last1=Bialy |first1=Shmuel |last2=Loeb |first2=Abraham |title=Could Solar Radiation Explain ʻOumuamua's Peculiar Acceleration? |date=26 October 2018 |eprint=1810.11490v4|class=astro-ph.EP }}{{cite web |last=Loeb |first=Abraham |title=How to Search for Dead Cosmic Civilizations |url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/how-to-search-for-dead-cosmic-civilizations/ |date=26 September 2018 |work=[[Scientific American]] |accessdate=26 September 2018 }} Other scientists have stated that the available evidence is insufficient to consider such a premise.[https://phys.org/news/2018-11-scientists-harvard-alien-spacecraft-theory.html Scientists push back against Harvard 'alien spacecraft' theory]. Kerry Sheridan, PhysOrg. 7 November 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/oumuamua-oh-interstellar-object-actually-225825249.html|title=‘Oumuamua, oh my! Was interstellar object actually an alien solar sail? Not so fast|last=Boyle|first=Alan|date=2018-11-06|website=Yahoo!|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-08}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.zeit.de/wissen/2018-11/oumuamua-lichtsegel-ausserirdische-aliens|title=Glaubt dieser Harvard-Professor selbst, was er sagt?|last=Schadwinkel|first=Alina|date=2018-11-08|work=Zeit Online|access-date=2018-11-08}} In response, [[Avi Loeb]] wrote an article detailing six anomalous properties of `Oumuamua that make it unusual, unlike any comets or asteroids seen before.{{cite web |last=Loeb |first=Abraham |authorlink=Avi Loeb |title=6 Strange Facts about the Interstellar Visitor 'Oumuamua |url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/6-strange-facts-about-the-interstellar-visitor-oumuamua/ |date=20 November 2018 |work=[[Scientific American]] |accessdate=20 November 2018 }} A subsequent report on observations by the Spitzer Space Telescope set a tight limit on cometary outgassing of any carbon-based molecules and indicated that `Oumuamua is at least ten times more shiny than a typical comet.{{cite arxiv |last1=Trilling |first1=David |last2=al. |first2=et |title=Spitzer Observations of Interstellar Object 1I/`Omumuamua |date=20 November 2018 |eprint=1811.08072v1|class=astro-ph.EP }} A detailed podcast produced by Rob Reid provides the full details about the differences between `Oumuamua and known comets.{{cite web |last=Reid |first=Rob |title=Is `Oumuamua a Comet? |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2018/11/nailing-down-the-nature-of-oumuamua-its-probably-a-comet-but/ |date=29 November 2018 |work=[[Ars Technica]] |accessdate=29 November 2018 }} On November 27, 2018, [[Avi Loeb]] and his undergraduate student at Harvard College, Amir Siraj, proposed a search for `Oumuamua-like objects which are trapped in the Solar System as a result of losing orbital energy through a close encounter with Jupiter.{{cite arxiv |last1=Siraj |first1=Amir |last2=Loeb |first2=Abraham |title=Identifying Interstellar Objects Trapped in the Solar System through Their Orbital Paramteters |date=27 November 2018 |eprint=1811.09632v2|class=astro-ph.EP }} They identified 4 candidates for trapped interstellar objects that could be visited by dedicated missions, and pointed out that future sky surveys, such as with LSST, should find many more. == Hypothetical space missions == {{main|Project Lyra}} ʻOumuamua was at first thought to be traveling too fast for any existing spacecraft to reach.{{Cite magazine |url=http://astronomynow.com/2017/11/22/an-interstellar-interloper-is-dashing-through-our-solar-system |title=An interstellar interloper is dashing through our solar system |magazine=Astronomy Now |last=Clarke |first=Stephen |date=22 November 2017 |access-date=24 November 2017 |language=en-US |df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2017/11/so-you-want-to-send-a-probe-to-catch-up-to-oumuamua/ |title=Chasing ʻOumuamua – unfortunately human technology isn't up to the task |quote=Chemical propulsion just doesn’t close the case in this scenario. |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=22 November 2017 |website=Ars Technica |access-date=23 November 2017 |df=dmy-all}} The [[Initiative for Interstellar Studies]] (i4is) launched [[Project Lyra]] to assess the feasibility of a mission to ʻOumuamua.{{cite web |title=Project Lyra – A Mission to ʻOumuamua |url=https://i4is.org/what-we-do/technical/project-lyra/ |website=I4IS |publisher=Initiative for Interstellar Studies}} Several options for sending a spacecraft to ʻOumuamua within a time-frame of 5 to 10 years were suggested. One option is using first a Jupiter flyby followed by a close solar flyby at {{convert|3|solar radius|e6km e6mi|sigfig=2|lk=in}} in order to take advantage of the [[Oberth effect]]. Different mission durations and their velocity requirements were explored with respect to the launch date, assuming direct impulsive transfer to the intercept trajectory. Using a powered Jupiter flyby, a solar Oberth maneuver and Parker Solar Probe heat shield technology, a Falcon Heavy-class launcher would be able to launch a spacecraft of dozens of kilograms towards 1I/ʻOumuamua, if launched in 2021.{{CN|date=November 2018}} More advanced options of using solar, laser electric, and laser sail propulsion, based on [[Breakthrough Starshot]] technology, have also been considered. The challenge is to get to the asteroid in a reasonable amount of time (and so at a reasonable distance from Earth), and yet be able to gain useful scientific information. To do this, decelerating the spacecraft at ʻOumuamua would be "highly desirable, due to the minimal science return from a hyper-velocity encounter". If the investigative craft goes too fast, it would not be able to get into orbit or land on the asteroid and would fly past it. The authors conclude that, although challenging, an encounter mission would be feasible using near-term technology. Seligman and Laughlin{{Cite journal |last1=Seligman |first1=Darryl |last2=Laughlin |first2=Gregory |title=The Feasibility and Benefits of in situ Exploration of ʻOumuamua-like Objects |journal=The Astronomical Journal |volume=155 |issue=5 |pages=217 |date=12 April 2018 |arxiv=1803.07022v2|doi=10.3847/1538-3881/aabd37 }} adopt a complementary approach to the Lyra study but also conclude that such missions, though challenging to mount, are both feasible and scientifically attractive. ==Other interstellar objects== Astronomers estimate that several interstellar objects of extrasolar origin (like ‘Oumuamua) pass inside the orbit of Earth each year, and that 10,000 are passing inside the orbit of Neptune on any given day.{{Cite interview |last=Fraser |first=Wesley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b09rvpts/the-sky-at-night-the-mystery-of-oumuamua |title=The Sky at Night: The Mystery of ‘Oumuamua |date=11 Feb 2018 |publisher=BBC |interviewer=[[Chris Lintott]]}} If the estimate is correct, this provides future opportunities for studies of interstellar objects. However, with current space technology, close visits and orbital missions are challenging due to their high speeds, though not impossible. In November 2018, Harvard astronomers reported that there should be hundreds of 'Oumuamua-size interstellar objects in the Solar System, based on calculated orbital characteristics, and presented several known examples, namely, [[2011 SP25]], [[2017 RR2]], [[2017 SV13]], and [[2018 TL6]].{{cite journal |last1=Siraj |first1=Amir |last2=Loeb |first2=Abraham |title=Identifying Interstellar Objects Trapped in the Solar System through Their Orbital Parameters |url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/1811.09632.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |date=29 November 2018 |journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] |volume=000 |pages=1-5 |accessdate=1 December 2018 }} These are all orbiting the sun, but with unusual orbits, and are assumed to have been trapped at some occasion. == See also == * [[C/2017 U7]], a non-interstellar hyperbolic comet discovered 10 days after ʻOumuamua, announced in March 2018 * [[C/2018 C2]], another non-interstellar hyperbolic comet, announced in March 2018 * [[(514107) 2015 BZ509|{{mp|(514107) 2015 BZ|509}}]], an asteroid with possible interstellar origin == Notes == {{reflist|group="Note"}} == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |title=MPEC 2017-U181: COMET C/2017 U1 (PANSTARRS) |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K17/K17UI1.html |website=[[Minor Planet Center]] |publisher=[[International Astronomical Union]] |date=25 October 2017 |access-date=25 October 2017}} (CK17U010) {{cite web |last1=Antier |first1=K. |title=A/2017 U1, first interstellar asteroid ever detected!
